column1: question
What type of design was used?
column4: block design | event related design | mixed

column1: Clearly describe each condition and the stimuli used.
column2: Be sure to completely describe baseline (e.g. blank white/black screen, presence of fixation cross, or any other text), especially for resting ­state studies. When possible provide images or screen snapshots of the stimuli
column21: RELEVANT TO DESCRIBE THE INCLUDED STUDIES

column1: Number of trials/blocks per run per condition
column2: Specify per run, and if differing by subject, specify summary statistics (mean, range and/or standard deviation) of such counts

column1: What was the duration of one block? (in seconds)
What was the duration of one trial? (in seconds)
Provide the timing structure of the events in the task, whether a random / jittered pattern or a regular arrangement; any jittering of block onsets
What was the intertrial interval range?
What was the intertrial interval distribution?
How many runs were used?
What was the duration of each imaging run in seconds?
What was the software used for stimuli presentation?
column4: Psychtoolbox | psychopy | e prime | presentation | cogent

column1: What was the software version used for stimuli presentation?
What operating system was used to present the stimuli?
Specify the URL of the experiment code if possible
Enumerate the conditions and fully describe and reference each.
column2: Consider using a shorthand name, e.g. AUDSTIM, VISSTIM, to refer to each condition, to clarify the distinction between a specific modelled effect and a psychological construct. Naming should reflect the distinction between instruction periods and actual stimuli, and between single parameters and contrasts of parameters

column1: Specify the instructions given to subjects for each condition
column2: Ideally copy the exact text. For resting ­state, be sure to indicate eyes­ closed, eyes­ open, any fixation. Describe if the subjects received any rewards during the task.

column1: Specifics of stimuli used in each run.
column2: For example, the unique number of stimuli used, and whether/how stimuli were repeated over trials or conditions

column1: Was the block or event ordering deterministic or randomized?
Specify inter-trial distritbution and blocklength
Describe how and the criteria used to constrain the orders/timings
Specify the presentation hardware
column4: back projection | in­ room display | goggles

column1: How were responses collected?
column4: motor response (button boxes) |  motor response (other) |  other

column1: Order in which tasks / runs are conducted
Was the order of the stimuli counterbalanced (across runs, across participants)?
Stimuli apparent size
Viewing distance
Clarity (i.e.,visual contrast, intensity, etc.)
Color
site of the stimulation
position in the visual field
Display device and method of projection (including refresh rate or response time of the monitors)
Note if differences in intensity or contrast between different stimulus conditions
Stimulus properties (e.g., frequency content, duration, onset/offset envelope, etc.)
Intensity
column2: e.g., relative to the subject’s individual hearing threshold, or as Sound Pressure Level [dB SPL]

column1: Ear of stimulation
column2: e.g., ear inserts, panel speakers, etc.

column1: Type, manufacturer and model of the delivery device
Further, the presence of contralateral ear masking stimulation, and its intensity, should be noted.
Stimuili database
calibration procedure
column2: including software (type, version and operating system) and hardware used, should also be described. Where relevant, the rationale for selecting a specific parameter (e.g., contrast, harmonic content) should be indicated. If features were determined individually for each participant, the criteria and the psychophysical method used should be detailed.

column1: Stimulus type (e.g., electrical, air puff)
Stimulus characteristics (e.g., duration, frequency)
Location on the body with reference to anatomical landmarks
column2: location on the body with reference to anatomical landmarks, and strength (ideally with respect to some sensory or motor threshold) should be reported. The distance between the site of peripheral stimulation and brain, and skin temperature are also important as they will affect response latency independent of the experimental manipulation.

column1: Was was the intensity of the stimulus?
column2: Ideally with respect to some sensory or motor threshold.

column1: Describe in detail any other stimulation not involving auditory, visual or somatosensory stimuli
Were feedbacks provided to the participant?
What variables were recorded?
column21: IMPORTANT TO DESCRIBE STUDIES OR FOR INCLUSION CRITERIA

column2: Summaries of behavior sufficient to establish that subjects were performing the task as expected. For example, correct response rates and/or response times, summarized over subjects (e.g. mean, range and/or standard deviation)
